reviews.review_text: I'm being completely honest when I say this. This would be an amazing game if it weren't for the absolutely garbage combat. Like it's really damn sad. There's this amazing world, all this lore that already exists, interesting story and characters. But the combat is just pathetic. I have no idea what the hell I'm even playing. It's like real time combat where you have to use action points like in the older Fallout games or Wasteland 2. EVERYTHING, but the combat, is amazing. But since the combat is such a vital part of the game I can't recommend Game of Thrones. I watched the entire show and read some of the books but story can only get you so far.  It's a damn shame.

I'm a huge fan of the Song of Ice and Fire series. I've watched the TV Show, and I'm currently reading the books; and I find this game completely amazing. Despite of the inadequate graphical designing, the game is still decent and worth playing. The extremely rich story is what's keeping me into it. I highly recommend this to every Song of Ice and Fire's fan, as it's really delightful and amazing to be able to walk around Castle Black and/or Westeros freely.

In spite of it's myriad flaws as a game, the writing and characters are so compelling that I found myself playing despite not really having any fun with the game's mechanics. The final chapters are exquisite and completely transcend the game's low budget conventions. And I'm not really a fan of Game of Thrones either. But this is a fine example of what a really good team can do on a budget.   Definitely recommended to fans of the Witcher and old Gothic games.

Ten hours in. Was almost turned away by negative reviews but decided I enjoyed the books and show too much to not try it. Good decision. The story is great and the combat is very similar to Knights of the Old Republic. I don't see myself regretting being tired at work from playing this game after the kids go to bed anytime soon.

Truly an underrated gem.. Dont be fooled by all those rewiewers which quitted after 10 mins if you like mature story-driven RPGs and/or are a fan of the books you'll love this.  The best story i've ever seen in a videogame, (and i'm quite into storydriven) if you read the books you'll surely notice Martin's touch :), the dialogues and the main charaters are also excellent, the choice system is one of the best i've seen and the choiches are truly meaningful... what more can i say? Yeah it also last quite longer than other modern rpgs it took almost 30 hours to me to finish my first playthrough and i also skipped a few secondary missions.   The combat was criticized as one of the weak point of this title but is actually quite good, a bit repetitive and boring at the start while you unlock new techniques and moves it truly start to shine.. a few hours into the game it's already very satisfying, it also require you to play it tactically and on knight (medium) difficulty it's already truly challenging and unforgiving in later stages.  The graphics are good enough when maxed, expecially the lights effects, for some reasons some of the most common (medium) armor in the games seems low tex  Sadly there a few aspects where clearly emerge that the devs were short of money like repeating models and bad voice actors for common npcs (the voice actors for the protagonist and others main characters are very good though) and some other unpolished aspects but these are really minor drawbacks in an overall memorable experience.. also with all the choices and the class sistem there surely enough material for second or third playthrough.  In the end i still consider this one of the best RPGs i've had the pleasure to play, if you are a fan of the books and/or mature story driven games this is truly a must buy.

+Great Story +Play as a Worg +Play as a Red Priest +There is an achievement called 'Pimp'   -Keyboard and Mouse controls make running/moving in the desired direction a major pain  8/10- Would use my dog to rip out midieval throats again

Great game. A must if you are into the Song of Ice and Fire lore.   Everyone says the control are horrible, but it is literally WASD movement with a resident evil over the shoulder camera. Switch party members by pushing tab. In combat, its like an mmo, where you auto attack and have a hotbar full of skills to use. You can push space bar and the game goes into slow motion, allowing you to be very strategic with combat and use your party members to their full extent.   Honestly if you had issues with the controls in this game you will have issues with the controls in a lot of games, because they are very simple and intuitive. I would imagine everyone complaining is using a controller, and then it might be more difficult, but its a joy on keyboard/mouse.   The story runs parallel with the books/show, so you are playing alongside important events in the world. It really is a lot of fun seeing the world from other points of view if you have read the books or seen the show. The character creation and leveling up has depth, it is a lot like an old school rpg. It has a smattering of dungeons and dragons, in that you get to pick your stats and skills.   All in all, great game, great rpg. Not the best, and a bit dated graphics wise, but that barely puts a dent in it. Would recommend.
A definitive recommendation for GoT and/or RPG Fans that can enjoy a very good story over outdated graphics and mediocre gameplay!

Very simple RPG mechanics in a intresting world. It was alot better then I expected. If you are a fan of the books or TV show (both) then this game is worth the money without question. In is it's own little story set before the first book, I was really enjoying it.   Also like the book it is told from multiple perspectives and you play diffrent characters. A surprisingly strong RPG for a game based on a franchise. Even your early choices matter later in the game. Gameplay could use a bit more polish and the game as a whole could have benefited from larger budget, but its OK since the most interesting part of it is the story, cruel and unforgiving just like the books it is based on. Definitely recommended for those who like the original books or TV series.

This is a *must* if you are both a fan of RPGs and Game of Thrones alike.  You play as two completely independant characters - Alester and Mors. Alester is royalty, while Mors has 'taken the black', living a life alongside an army defending all mankind from any and all threats that may lie beyond an enormous ice structure known as 'the wall'. The motives of these two characters differ on many important points, and this game is a journey to discover how their paths affect one another. Knowledge of the TV series or books is not a prerequisite to enjoying this game, but it certainly is a perk.  Now, I seriously discourage anyone from buying this that has a habit of skipping cutscenes and dialog. Cutscenes and role-playing dialog are more than 50% of this game’s true content. It’s essentially an interactive 25+ hour movie, written by George RR Martin himself. The story is deep, the acting ranges from passable to superb, and it all absolutely ties in to the lore of the TV show. You make dialog decisions that can and will affect the outcome of the game, and in many cases, affect the outcome of your present mission. Almost every fight can be talked out of, if you care to figure out how to calm the person you’re speaking to. Adversely, you could tell the angry person to shut their mouth and prepare for a beating, if you wish.  Combat is cool-down style, and fights can be slowed down to bullet-time to make tactical decisions, which you will be doing A LOT. Auto-attacking will get you killed, period. You must use buffs and special attacks which are unlocked with XP, which is gained by completing missions, discovering new areas, and defeating enemies.  Standard RPG fanfare such as inventory, loot, bartering, side-quests, open-world exploration, hidden items, character leveling, upgrades, stats, potions, and armor & weapon slots are all present as well. Enjoy!
A great representation of the books, but the controls are unbareable and not changable. Really making this impossible to play and enjoy.

As a Game of Thrones fan of both the TV series and the Books I thought the naritive of this game was top notch and for that alone I would remomend it to any other game of thrones fans. However as a game, it doesn't hold up as much. The controls are clunky and weird and the camera control was a pain.  If you are just looking for a solid RPG tital then perhaps try else where, or pick this game up during a steam sale if you have a few bucks to spare. You'll easily get an entertaining 30 hours out of the game with the DLC.  Over all, it was an OK game with sub par gameplay but with an above average story with interesting characters.  Score: 6/10

For a game released in 2012 this game comes across as rather unpolished in a few respected - the voice acting is a bit rough, the graphics could use some work, and sometimes the combat is frustrating. But for all it's faults, it gives you come interesting and complex characters and a monster of a story befitting the intrigues of Westeros. I give this game a hearty recommendation to any fan, because it's an extremely worthwhile story in it's own right and a great contribution to the series.

I'm a big fan of the show as well as 'A Song of Ice and Fire' novels, the game is no different, I love the 'lore' and there's quite a bit to be had in this game, despite the great story and characters(dialogue/voice) this game is far from perfect, sometimes it looks great and other times it looks absolutly horrible, animations are lacking and there's A LOT of backtracking... on foot... which artifically extends the length of the game, however, it's still worth the purchase (if your a fan of the series) in the end I had a good time and I give it a 'thumbs up' - 7/10

Game of Thrones really surprised me, I did not expect to get such an overall pleasant playthrough. Having only heard bad things about the game it took me awhile to finally install it and give it a chance, and I regret not doing it sooner. The game offers a really nice story where to get to play as Mors, a member of the Nights Watch and Alester, a red priest and each with their own interesting backgrounds. What really impressed me was how the story progressed and really chocked me sometimes, there's always going to happen something that you did not expect. One thing that really bugged me however was that the choices you make (and you'll be making alot) didn't have that much of an impact in the story, it felt like they added choices just to have more dialogue. Another thing is the voice acting, Some are good, Some are bad, Most of the time when characters talk to eachother it feels more like they're just saying their line instead of actually talking.  The combat is also something that could have used some more work, I found it hard to effectively switch targets in realtime and some abilities are just overpowered. However they did make it alot about interupting attacks and combining attacks between characters which I really enjoyed.  Overall I would say that the game was definatly worth the money and time and I would gladly recommend it to anyone that is a fan of Game of Thrones or RPG.

Well, this is one of the most deep and rewarding stories I've ever seen in a game. The graphics are a bit dated, combat is good, but nothing remarkable, but the world and the story are awe-inspiring. Much better than any of AAA titles I've ever seen, BioWare games including.  The game lists GRRM as a consultant and probably it is no brag as it meticulously recreates every detail of Westeros and mentiones and involves as minors many reconizable caracters, some even having the looks and being voiced over by the actors from the series.  9,5/10 --- Perfect

This game could have been--and should have been--great. The story was written by George R.R. Martin himself, and it fits into the the overall story of A Song of Ice and Fire well. That said, the game clearly had a low budget. The graphics and animations are bad, the combat is boring and repetive, the environments are bland, and most of the voice acting is grating. It's almost funny how some of the characters are endearing despite looking and sounding like crap. The one saving grace is the traits system, which actually rewards (or punishes) you via stat buffs/debuffs depending on what choices you make throughout the story.  This game is almost worth playing thru for the story, but you would probably be better off reading a synopsis or watching a Let's Play video. As it stands, it's a 4/10 pass for this one.
8/10 Would Swag

It has minor bugs and you may need to use the FOV fix to zoom out the camera. Some voice acting is low budget but nothing like SOTN. Definitely purchase this on sale.

Still: the decisionmaking matters, quests can dynamically succeed or fail in various degrees and the story is actually pretty engaging (even though a bit forced). not sure if i would recommend this for full price but on a decent sale this game is a steal. in doubt: set combat difficulty to easy and play it more like the telltales version!

If you are not familiar with the series or the books you might be disappointed with how the story turns out. It is a solid story telling game, so if you are interested in a good (and dark) story you should give it a try.  Cons:  From the technical aspect the game is far from up to date. Also the intput and GUI is 'consolish' and needs some time. If, like me, you're a fan of Game of Thrones and you enjoy RPGs mainly for the story, this game is great. The story is one of the best I've seen in a video game. However, the combat, controls, and visuals are all pretty much just adequate. There are a good number of small bugs mainly dealing with the camera and walking controls. The voice acting is also pretty hit and miss with people mispronouncing names and speaking as if they don't understand the context of what they're saying.

This is a low budget game, take note of that before buying it. But despite that, it still managed to entertain me and the story itself is a dark one, wherein your choices will shape how the game world will react to you and it will affect how the game plays and how the game will end. The combat in this game isn't as refined but it isn't half-♥♥♥♥♥. I found myself enjoying the many skill combinations that allowed me to mete out death to my many opponents. The graphics aren't as good as other games released in 2012 but they are good in their own right, i personally loved how the heavy armors looked. Very imposing, very powerful and lord-like.  I dislike the fact that you cannot replay the chapters or any of the missions at all without starting a new game and the fact that there is no new game+ option. Such a shame, i would have loved to explore other decisions in specific chapters in game without having to replay the whole thing again. The idle animations default to that one pose where the hand is on the hip for some reason, it looks awkward as the player character and many of the npc ones shift from a talking animation to the hand+hip idle every 2 seconds.  All in all, i recommend this game for the story and the enjoyment i got out of it and i think you will enjoy the game as well despite the flaws it has. Get it in a bundle or on sale, doesn't matter. Just get it. Hell, George R.R. Martin is in the game. 8/10
Good if you really love the lore of Game of Thrones, however if you want gameplay over story, I wouldn't reccomend it.

One of the worst RPG games I've played in a long time. Even though the plot seems interesting, it has a lot of issues that make it, in my opinion, unplayable. The battles become repetitive too early in the game, and it has a graphic glitch in some places where you just can't look at some parts of the scenario because it freezes for a while.

*Disclaimer, I only played this game for an hour, so take this opinion in that context and weigh it accordingly*  Picked this up for 65p, and I'm glad I only paid that. The reviews of this game were pretty mediocre and I knew that going in, however I thought playing it knowing of it's dodgy quality would somehow make me tolerant of it's shortcomings. I was wrong.  In the main, it was the voice acting and dialogue which killed this game for me, I just couldn't get over how bad it is. Does that sound snobbish? Perhaps... but when every conversation had me wincing internally... I knew I wouldn't be able to plough through this game.   That said, in my opinion I think the combat is actually worse. It is a kind of real time, MMORPG style combat reminiscent of World of Warcraft. You queue up actions and attacks with special abilities taking up 'energy', while standard attacks can be laid upon your enemies forever. There is no blocking animations or reactions to being hit, they just chop and hack away at one another until one falls down... very much like the early MMORPGs. The only difference to the formula here is you can hold in space bar to slow the game down to a crawl, like a real time active pause.. should you feel the need to do so.  Special attacks might hit multiple enemies or add a status effect like 'stun' or 'bleeding' but it is really unsatisfying. Those of you who like that kind of combat... I'd say you should still steer clear of this. I played WoW for years and believe me when I say whatever itch that game scratches with it's combat... Game of Thrones doesn't.  These two elements alone were enough for me to abandon Game of Thrones only a hour in. Some may argue I hadn't given it a chance... but to be honest first impressions stick with me when it comes to games, mainly because there are just so so so many others in my collection that I could be spending my finite free time on. Perhaps that is shallow... but I suppose I'm so long in the tooth as a gamer now, you just know when a game isn't going to improve.  So be warned... Winter is coming... but you can spend it indoors playing a lot better games than this.

Combat is ok, and you are able to do some basic character customization. However the story is designed to be very linear. I personally could not make the decisions that I wanted to make. Again, the game is all about telling an existing story with just a little variation. If you are ok with that you could very well enjoy this game. You are able to turn off the blood, but the foul language is a little harsh. Too bad they don't let you turn that off.

I'm not sure why this game gets such a low score (58). Just for the epic story alone I'd give it at least a 70. Sadly this game was released before FOCUS realized its combat system was garbage and was repelling 40% of the people who would otherwise buy their games. While a step up from Of Orcs and Men, it still falls very short of enjoyable.  If you aren't aware of the combat system, its a mix of strategy turn-based and hack-n-slash. You plug in attacks x,y,x and then your character does attacks x,y,x in sequence - not as you press it. This means youre basically standing still creating sequences of attacks before you even know what the oppenent is going to do - almost like rock, paper, scissors. (the slow reaction time / animations mean that you can't do it in real time, even if you wanted too). It's disgusting and doesn't feel right to play. Doesn't feel like youre actually controlling the character, its strange.  If you can bear the clunky, semi-realtime combat - I'm sure this game would be great.

Well, it's definitely Game of Thrones. I suppose there's no better way for a game to make you feel attached to a character before watching them die.  It was a little slow to start, but the story became incredibly captivating about half way through; the ending especially. You play as two characters: a brother of the Night's Watch, and a Red Priest returning to Westeros. The gameplay is similar to Dragon Age: Origins.  While the game mechanics are clunky and the graphics aren’t anything to be excited over, I'm glad I decided to play this game, which had been sitting in my games list (never installed) for a year or two.  I recommend playing if you have some time to kill (25 hours or so), and are looking for a good story which attempts to tie into the Season 1 Game of Thrones universe. I also recommend setting the game to the 'Squire' difficulty to ease possible frustrations (has no effect on achievements).

One of the best RPGs I have played. A range of small but meaningful innovations, great story and awesome settings. Of course the game has issues with production values but it has some great ideas that have to be supported. Hope we see developers with larger budgets pick some of those ideas up.  Definitely give this one a go and especially don't give up during the first few chapters as things are building up slowly, both story and game play wise.

Game of Thrones title is fully earned here - evil will triumph and the innocent blood will grease the gears of political schemes.  Writing is the main course here - the plot takes place shortly after Robert Baratheon's death, when the king's bast... errm... illegitimate children are being hunted. We have two main characters with separate storylines and motives, but they will be forced to take part in the political events. The atmosphere is very bleak, treachery lurks everywhere. The game features some of the most disturbing scenes in gaming - done so well, that the worst one isn't even graphic.  There are a lot of smaller and bigger choices to make, the consequences are often non-direct or delayed - but they have impact on the plot.  The game is off-putting at the beginning - the visuals are outdated (though some of the textures, armors etc. look weirdly good) and the combat feels slow and boring. But if only you'll stay a bit longer, hopefully you'll find yourself in the story's grip. The graphics will still be awful, but servicable. Combat will pick up a bit though once you'll learn more skills and get more stamina to use them - it will still be a bit boring as it's very tactical and focues on disabling and exploiting enemies (at higher difficulty levels it's very challenging).  Get the Beyond of Wall DLC if you decide to play the game - it's a short prequel and it's great.

This game is not as bad as some would have you think. If you enjoyed Game of Thones and like old school controls then its worth picking this game up.  Story : In brief you get a decent storyline to follow and you also get to make decisions that change certain elements of the story. Voice acting could have been better.  Controls : The controls are just how older pc games used to handle, I think people that have a problem with it are just used to the refined console fighting controls, its not all that bad.  Graphics : Yes the graphics are dated considering its a recent release, still playable but if you want stunning Crysis-like graphics this is not for you.  If you can pick this game up in a sale as I did its a great buy, is it worth full price? not for me, but it would not have been the worst game I paid full price for.  7 / 10

For a game based on a TV show*, it's pretty good. While I normally prefer turn-based combat, the real-time-with-pause works pretty well. You have to balance inflicting status effects (on fire, stunned, knocked down, etc.) with matching extra powered attacks while always saving a bit of power to throw in an interrupt. You're often controlling 2 characters (and sometimes also a dog), so there is a lot of room for strategy. Like most real-time-with-pause systems though, the fights always devolve into a big pile of guys bouncing all over the place.  The story is really about as good as it gets for something like this. It all takes place before the show starts and focuses on new characters who often run into characters from the show. The writing is ok, and the story is interesting. Some of the side quests are fun.  There are a lot of negatives though. Some of the quest are really wonky - you have to basically try every dialogue option. It seemed like a crap-shoot to figure out the best dialogue option. The results were just too random.   The visuals are all over the place. The main two character's faces look great, but some of the cast members are almost unrecognizable. The texture quality is often pretty bad. For example, the doors look like something from a 10-year-old game: just a flat texture on a very thin bit of polygons. Like, the handles are never modeled making them look really out of place. Tree, flowers, etc. often look terrible. Oh, it's also worth mentioning that the game is over-the-shoulder third-person, so it can be a real pain to look around. As far as I could tell there was no first-person 'look' option. The FOV was really low, as well.  The difficulty curve is a bit off. Most fights were easy, even many 'elite' or 'boss' fights, but a few were suddenly extremely difficult.   In the end, Game of Thrones RPG is a fun little game that fans of the show can get some fun out of. It has some flaws, but overall I've had a good time.  * It features the likeness and voices of actors from the TV show, which is based on the books.

If you like the stories of Westeros, then I would say that this is worth buying when on sale. The story in itself is very good, though the game is no where near as polished as it should be.   The combat can be clunky as whilst it isnt turn based (You assign skills in a slowed down real time), it can be very repetitive and there are often clipping issues where the characters will either occupy the same space or 'vibrate' when they are standing half inside a wall. The system itself though is pretty easy to master once you understand the roles of each character (I always use Mors as a Landed knight and so he 'tanks' whilst Alester can damage the enemy)  The quest system can be frustrating too if you are new to RPG's as if you miss a slight detail, you will pretty much fail the side quests. Most of the side quests can be completed over several chapters, but if you miss a specific pickup that starts the quest in the chapter where it has become available then you won't be able to complete the quest once you have moved on in the story. This can be awkward for achievment hunters.   I do wonder how this story would have turned out if it had been developed by a bigger studio, as it is clear that the writers have tried to keep everything in keeping with the lore of Westeros. It does kind of feel like this game was made by a company who snapped up the license before anyone else could and then they rushed to push out the game to cash in.   All of that being said, if you are a fan of Game of Thrones and old style RPG's then I would recommend you buy this just for one playthrough. If you arent happy with slow turn based combat and linear levels, then I simply would not. I would also say that this game is not worth the full price and you should wait until you see it on sale somewhere.

Contrary to what most professional critics say, this game is actually quite enjoyable.  If you are a fan of ASoIaF and RPGs (and who isn't really?), getting it should be a no-brainer.   The game is a stripped down version of a Bioware-style RPG with a focus on a linear and tight narrative. The game has very little dialogue and content outside of the main narrative; for example, the only rewards for exploration of the often large areas are coin and lore entries, both being fairly insubstantial.   Typical RPG elements in this game like tactical combat and character building aren't particularly interesting, but neither are they horribly boring or badly done. But since it is not a strong suit of the game you might want to play on 'casual' to not be bothered too much about it.   The story has a nice flow, with familar themes from the books (or the show) being present while also managing to stand on its own. The game is told in alternating chapters of two different characters, engaging you in different aspects of the story. This is an experience rarely seen in video games, which makes this title stand out.   The dialogues are usually pretty good, but if you expect the same level of wit, sharpness, drama and authenticity as in the books you will be disappointed. This is a narrative RPG, with the main device of narration being cutscene dialogues, so you can expect an unnatural amount of exposition in the dialogues. The voice overs are a mixed bag. The cast is quite good in parts, but some lines are delivered painfully slow and the actors often seem aloof from the situation at hand. You get the impression that each line was recorded separately. (Of course, this is how it was done, but the job of both writers and actors is to keep you from noticing this)  The dialog system itself is similar to the wheel Bioware uses without the responses being pigeonholed into certain personality types. To make the choice between options more clear, the possible responses are worded in a more introspective style, often describing observations about the persons that will inform one's response or flat out stating one's motivation. This is actually a huge improvement over Bioware's use of the system, as it feels more like choosing the character's thought processes than just making a character conform to a personality.   If you are a hardcore fan of ASoIaF you might find some details unbelievable, but for the most part the game's story and dialogues fit fairly well into the setting.  If you ever wondered what a Bioware game would be like, if it was more linear and focussed almost completely on the main narrative, you might want to check this game out.  Edited: I nominated this for the plot-twist Steam Award.

This is easily the most underrated game I've played in a long time, if not ever. The story, characters, and the choices available to the character are all fantastic, and are reason enough for me to recommend this game to everyone.
